repnme.cdata!:
El Salvador - Agricultural Sector Reform
            and Investment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, highly likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, in addition to overall,
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank, and Borrower.
            Several lessons address the following. Once again,
            experience confirms that institutional reforms are more
            successful when supported by strong government commitments,
            for a sustained period of time, and reforms implemented
            incrementally, and in sequence. Regardless of success, it is
            suggested that institutional reforms are better handled as a
            technical assistance activity, or a stand-alone project
            separate from sectoral investments. In this case, the
            project might have been better designed as two inter-related
            and successive stages, and in addition, include a full
            assessment of local capacity to implement, and process
            project activities, and requirements. Nevertheless, the
            dynamic, changing nature of agricultural research and
            extension priorities, requires a system embodied in project
            design, so as to adjust focus, and priorities accordingly.
            This was particularly important because the project was
            implemented immediately after the end of the civil war, and
            later on, because farmers demonstrated interest in
            diversifying their production to higher value crops.
            Particularly because of post-conflict circumstances, due
            consideration should be given to other financers in the
            sector, clearly defining areas of intervention, either
            geographically or by task, to prevent overlap, and avoid
            driving down standards. Other lessons also address
            institutional arrangements, agreements with beneficiaries,
            training, and adequate performance indicators.

repnme.cdata!:
El Salvador - Agricultural Sector Reform
            and Investment Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will provide a vehicle for
            implementation of the Government of El Salvador's
            (GOES) agricultural development policy.  The project will
            help GOES to:  (a) implement its agricultural sector policy
            and strategy and agriculture-related parts of its National
            Reconstruction Plan; (b) strengthen its agricultural public
            sector through the reorganization and institutional
            development of the Ministry for Agriculture and Livestock
            (MAG) and the National Agricultural Technology Center
            (CENTA), and support services privatization; (c) accelerate
            the generation of more productive and environmentally
            sustainable agricultural technology through research; and
            (d) contribute to productivity improvements of small and
            medium size farmers by providing agricultural extension
            services.  The project has two components. First, the
            component on reform and institutional development at MAG and
            CENTA will finance technical assistance, equipment,
            training, civil works and incremental operating cost to
            support:  (a) managing and implementing MAG's
            institutional planning and strategy for reform and
            development; (b) rationalizing MAG and CENTA's human
            resources; (c) establishing management information systems
            and procedures; and (d) constructing a headquarters building
            for MAG. Second, the component of agricultural research and
            extension for small and medium farmers will finance
            technical assistance, vehicles, equipment, training, civil
            works rehabilitation, and incremental recurrent expenditures
            to support:  (a) research; (b) agricultural extension; and
            (c) support services for research and extension.
